instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
threads.message:
Hello,

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, no liquid damage, no history (customer told it's dead after sleep mode).

Board without battery, unplugged all connectors takes from charger:
20.33V
0.052A

Power rails:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.7V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 20.35V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.426V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> - 0V

no short on these rails
no heat through thermal camera

what should I check next?

thanks in advance, your help is appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
threads.message:
Do NOT quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Maintain forum aesthetic, please.

Post <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> levels.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
threads.message:
You have a problem on PMIC (<CHIP>U7800</CHIP>) area.
It receives <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, but doesn't send out enable for <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
Check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
threads.message:
I've found <SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> 0,01V, <RESISTOR>R7835</RESISTOR> high resistance and <CAPACITOR>C7844</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7843</CAPACITOR> shorted to ground. Replaced all three components and the system started!

[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] Many thanks for your help and patience! You've made a great job!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no liquid
threads.message:
I bet was only ONE cap shorted.
For the future, remove one by one and check each time if short has gone...
